Brooklyn Historical Society
The Packer Collegiate Institute records
Packer Collegiate Institute.
Brooklyn Female Academy
2014.019
283.6 Cubic Feet in 566 boxes, one flat file drawer, and one object
circa 1780 to 2016 The Packer Collegiate Institute records contain administrative records, financial records, architectural records, Board of Trustees records, student and faculty records, publications, photographs, audiovisual media, event ephemera, and memorabilia, dating from circa 1780 to 2016. Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Packer Collegiate Institute records, 2014.019, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Immediate Source of Acquisition note
Gift of the Packer Collegiate Institute, 2014. Prior to acquisition by BHS, the collection was managed by Packer's Alumni Association and its Development Office.
Processing Information note
The archival processing of the collection began in fall 2004 by students from Pratt Institute, School of Library and Information Science and concluded in spring 2008. A total of 159 graduate students participated in this project expending upwards of 6,500 processing hours. They are:

The records were donated to Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS) in 2014. In June 2015, BHS archivist John Zarrillo, assisted by Stephanie Coy, prepared the collection for transfer from Packer Collegiate Institute to BHS. This process included the consolidation of the collection from 445 boxes to 388 boxes. The collection's arrangement and description remained largely unchanged, although adjustments were made in certain areas to aid researchers. The finding aid and container list was converted from a Word document to an EAD XML file and imported into Archivists' Toolkit in July 2015.
In September 2015, John Zarrillo commenced processing approximately 80 cubic feet of records that remained on-site at Packer. This work was completed with the assistance of Katie Bednark and Laurin Paradise. Subsequently the arrangement and description of the collection was completely revised by the BHS archivist in June 2016.
In January 2017, the Packer Collegiate Institute collection (ARC.130), which was comprised of accessions 1985.061 and 1987.016, was incorporated into the Packer Collegiate Institute records (2014.019) by John Zarrillo. These materials include assorted catalogs, publications, and other ephemera. The provenance of those files is as follows: Portions of accession 1985.061 were the gifts of Katharine B. Cronkhite, 1960; Mrs. Joseph Keppler, 1966; Katherine W. Sawford, date unknown; and the Packer Collegiate Institute, date unknown. Remaining materials from this accession were acquired sometime prior to 1985. Accession 1987.016 was the gift of Georgia Giddings, 1987.
Historical note
The Packer Collegiate Institute was established as the Brooklyn Female Academy on Joralemon Street in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn in 1845. It was formed by a committee of local citizens who were interested in the education of young women. The school's first president was Dr. Alonzo Crittenden, who presided over a student body of 350 girls from 19 states.
The school burned down on New Years' Day, 1853, and reopened in 1854 with the assistance of a generous $65,000 gift—the largest donation to aid American secondary education at the time—from Mrs. Harriet Packer, widow of William Packer, and former trustee of the Brooklyn Female Academy. One condition of Packer's donation was her request for the dissolution of the Brooklyn Female Academy Corporation, which was to be replaced by what is today's Packer Collegiate Institute. Prominent Brooklyn architect Minard LaFever designed the Gothic Revival building, presently known as Founders Hall.
In 1883, after Crittenden's death, Truman Backus assumed the role of Packer's new president. As a result, religious studies ceased to be part of the curriculum. During this period, Packer rose to a position of national preeminence in female education. In 1887, the east wing, designed by Napoleon Le Brun, was built to house the gymnasium and science laboratories. In 1907, an Alumnae Hall was adjoined to the physical plant and the subway was constructed under Joralemon Street, which required the school to remove the observatory dome from the main building. Spanning the years 1908 to 1918, Edward Jasper Goodwin served as president and the students received letter grades for the first time.
John Denbigh succeeded Goodwin and served as president until 1938, overseeing the 1926 addition of the penthouse in Alumnae Hall. Denbigh presided over the establishment of Packer's Junior College in 1919. The school endured the financial impacts of the Great Depression, which resulted in teacher layoffs and salary cuts. In 1938 Paul Shafer became the fifth president of Packer and oversaw the Centennial celebration in 1945. During the 1950s, Packer's Junior College began awarding Associate Degrees and in 1957, Pratt Hall was added to Packer's growing complex of buildings. In 1968, President Shafer retired and Jack Skillman took over the post. In 1969, the school acquired nearby St. Ann's Church.
By 1972, the Institute experienced major changes, including the disbandment of the Junior College and the introduction of a co-ed student body. The elementary school was divided into Lower and Middle schools during this decade and Peter Esty became headmaster in 1982. Succeeding Esty was J. Geoffrey Pierson who served as the president of Packer from 1990 through 2004. Pierson oversaw the major renovation of the school's buildings and grounds, include the complete renovation of the St. Ann's Church building, which was was completed in 2003. Following Pierson's retirement, Bruce Dennis became the head of school in 2004.
Arrangement note
The records are organized into twenty three series:
Series 1: Charters and By-laws
Series 2: Board of Trustees records
Series 3: Student administrative records
Series 4: Circulars, catalogues, and curriculum guides
Series 5: Faculty records and papers
Series 6: Administrative committees and reports
Series 7: Financial records and Annual Reports
Series 8: Student Life
Series 9: School Events
Series 10: Presidents, Headmasters, and Heads of School
Series 11: Office of Public Relations
Series 12: Development Office, Fund Raising, and Alumni records
Series 13: Yearbooks
Series 14: Architectural records
Series 15: Packer History
Series 16: Music
Series 17: Photographs
Series 18: Audio, film, and video recordings
Series 19: Instructional materials
Series 20: Junior College
Series 21: Memorabilia
Series 22: Packer family
Series 23: Miscellaneous
Custodial History
Many items in the collection were donated by alumni to the Packer Collegiate Institute prior to acquisition by Brooklyn Historical Society. The identity of these donors has been noted in the finding aid whenever possible.
Scope and Contents
The Packer Collegiate Institute records contain administrative records, financial records, architectural records, correspondence, student and faculty records, publications, photographs, audiovisual media, and memorabilia, dating from circa 1780 to 2016.
The records relate to the administrative and business activities of the Institute, including meeting minutes held between the Board of Trustees and other committees, annual reports from the President of Packer to the Board of Trustees, funding raising, and alumni affairs.
Student activities are well represented in the collection. Files relating to students include student publications, yearbooks, theatrical programs, scrapbooks, student notebooks, numerous photographs, and audiovisual recordings.
Overall, the records document the history of women's education in Brooklyn, New York, and the community's rich cultural heritage.
Conditions Governing Access note
Student records and personnel files are closed to researchers for 100 years from their date of creation. All other files are open to researchers without restriction.
The majority of the records in this collection are housed off-site. Please contact the BHS library for more information on the availibity of specific boxes ( library@brooklynhistory.org).
Conditions Governing Use note
Copyright held by the Packer Collegiate Institute. All uses beyond fair use requires a licensing agreement as per Title 17 of the U.S. Copyright Law.
Photographs of individuals and records pertaining to individual students or staff cannot be reproduced for commercial purposes.
Related Archival Materials note
The following collections also hold material relating to the Packer Collegiate Institute:
School composition books and diaries collection (1977.348) - Contains school composition books and diaries dating from 1849 to 1901 and belonging to various Brooklyn residents, including Maggie E. Briggs (a student at Packer Collegiate Institute).
Lillian F. Robbins certificate from the Regents of the University of the State of New York (1977.414) - Certificate issued to Packer Collegiate Institute student in 1872.
Brooklyn schools collection (1985.054) - Includes records on over seventy Brooklyn schools, dating from 1828 to 2015.
Blackburne, Woodward, and Ottaway family papers (2013.006) - Includes the papers of Packer alumna Mary B. Woodward (1871-1943).
Henry Nagel papers (2015.004) - Includes items belong to Packer alumna Winifred Gladys Nagel Pitt, including Supplementary Reading for the Academic and Collegiate Schools booklet (1922), Class Day program (1931), the Annual Sermon to the Graduating Class (1931), clippings, photographs, and an address titled "Bender of the Twig" by school President Paul D. Schafer (1939).
Allen J. Kone collection of Brooklyn postcards (2016.014) - Contains Packer Collegiate Institute postcards.
Jacques Cortelyou papers (ARC.025) - Includes a Report of the Treasurer of the Brooklyn Female Academy (later the Packer Collegiate Institute).
Other Finding Aids
Item-level records for the collection are available for searching via the Image Database in the library and the online image database.
A website about the history of The Packer Collegiate Institute is browsable here.

Series 1: Charters and By-laws1.6 Cubic Feetin four boxes1847-2004
Arrangement
Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
The series contains charters and by-laws of the Brooklyn Female Academy (BFA) and the Packer Collegiate Institute, dating from 1847 to 2004.
The act to incorporation and by-laws of the BFA are also included in bound volumes of the school's circulars, catalogues, and reports located in Series 4: Circulars, catalogues, and curriculum guides (boxes 509-510) and Sub-series 6.2: Administrative reports (box 507).Act of Incorporation, Articles of Association and By-laws of the Brooklyn Female Academy, together with a list of Stockholders, The Trustees' Second Annual Report, Treasurer's Statement1847Charter and By-laws1896, 1922, 1940Amendments to Charter certificate1919Charters and By-laws (13 pamphlets)1940-1964Amended Charter authorizing Packer to award AA and AAS degrees1941Amendments to Charter certification2004Series 2: Board of Trustees records8.25 Cubic Feetin seventeen boxes1844-2000
Scope and Contents
The series contains records of the Board of Trustees of Packer Collegiate Institute, dating from 1844 to 2000. It is primarily composed of meeting minutes, which include information regarding admissions, finances, extracurricular issues, student and faculty life, alumni gifts and development, and issues pertaining to the operations and welfare of the school. The series also contains a small amount of correspondence.

Scope and Contents
The series contains various student administrative records, dating from circa 1860 to 1979. These include reports of Scholarship and Promotion, academic transcripts, attendance and admission records, and Regents Examinations.
Arrangement
The series is organized into six sub-series:
Sub-series 3.1: Reports of Scholarship and Promotion
Sub-series 3.2: Secondary and Junior College Transcripts
Sub-series 3.3: Elementary Student Transcripts
Sub-series 3.4: Transcripts and Report Cards (all grades)
Sub-series 3.5: Attendence and Admission records
Sub-series 3.6: Regents ExaminationsSub-series 3.1: Reports of Scholarship and Promotion8.6 Cubic Feetin nineteen boxescirca 1860-1979
Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains records of scholarship and promotion (or academic transcripts) of Packer Collegiate Institute students, dating from circa 1860 to 1979.
It includes:
Permanent Record of Promotions for 1869 and 1884; Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship circa 1883-1898; Permanent Record: Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship 1899-1911, vol. I-VIII.
Two bound ledgers titled Permanent Record of Promotions, 1869 and 1884. Student transcripts including the year of promotion to each grade and graduation. Promotion dates circa 1860-1898.
Sixteen bound ledgers titled Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship, dated between 1883 and 1898. Student transcripts include student name, age, address, grade level and scholarship in various subjects. Arranged alphabetically by last name of student. Additional students are included in the index. Dates of admission, promotion, graduation or withdrawal are recorded as well as the school from which the student was admitted and the class to which he/she was assigned, and the college to which the student was admitted, if any.
Eight bound ledgers titled Permanent Record: Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship, 1899-1911, vol. I-VIII. Student transcripts with student name, age, address, department and grade. Arranged alphabetically by last name. Dates of admission, promotion, graduation or withdrawal are recorded, as well as the school from which the student was admitted and the class to which assigned, and college to which student was admitted, if any.
Two bound ledgers and one folder documenting students entering college, dating from 1927-1979.

Arrangement note
Arranged alphabetically by surname. Loose photographs that were unidentifiable are filed at the beginning of the series.
Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains the transcripts from the Packer Collegiate Institute Secondary School and Junior College, dating from 1922 to 1967. The transcripts include some or all of the following information: Student grades, dates entered and left Packer, date of birth, home address, parent's name(s), standardized test scores, extra-curricular activities, religious affiliation, and photographs. While most of the transcripts indicate if they are from either the Secondary School or the Junior College, there are some that remain ambiguous. There are records that contain information from both the Secondary School and the Junior College, and occasionally even Elementary School. Some transcripts show both maiden and married name if the student's status changed while attending the school. In most cases, the record is filed by maiden name. However, there are a few records where the maiden name was crossed out and replaced by the married name, in which case it is filed by the married name.Miscellaneous Photos1922-1967Abberley – Scope and Contents
This sub-series is comprised of student academic records, which were documented from circa 1900 to 1960. Records include report cards, transcripts, teacher comments, parent/teacher/student/principal correspondence, student photographs, and various notes (religious background, date of birth, parents' The sub-series contains student attendance and admission records dating from 1883 to the 1960s.List of student attendees1883-1884Attendence and Punctuality records1911-1948Form Letter and Notice of Admission1931Enrollment Reservation Requests, Confirmations1920-1930Application for admissioncirca 1950s-1960sSub-series 3.6: Regents Examinations0.5 Cubic Feetin nine folders1870-1950
Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains the Regents Examinations of Packer Collegiate Institute, dating from 1874 to 1882 and 1910 to 1950. There are some gaps between June 1931 and 1938, and no records for 1949. Information regarding student's age, address and grades on examinations in academic courses are handwritten in the booklets. The examinations were administered by the principal and signed by the deputies of examination. It also includes one Regents Exam confirmation, dating from 1870.Regents Exam List and Evaluation1874-1882Ring bound Regents Examinations1910-1911Unbound Regents Examinations1917-1919Unbound Regents Examinations1920-1922Unbound Regents Examinations1923-1925Unbound Regents Examinations1926-1928Unbound Regents Examinations1929-1931Unbound Regents Examinations1938-1950Regents Exam confirmation1870Series 4: Circulars, catalogues, and curriculum guides11.6 Cubic Feetin twenty five boxes1846-2007
Scope and Contents
The series contains Brooklyn Female Academy and Packer Collegiate Institute circulars, catalogues, curriculum guides, and supplements, dating from 1846 to 2007. The circulars and catalogues contain annual commencement exercises; lists of students and graduates, members of the board of trustees, faculty and staff; course of study; and historical notations. The later curriculum guides focus primarily on Packer's course of study. Of note is a pamphlet entitled "Packer and the War" that was produced circa 1943.
Curriculum guides for 1987 to 1989 are filed in Sub-series 12.4: Curriculum files.
Catalogues for the Packer's Junior College are filed in Sub-series 20.2: Subject files.

Sub-series 5.3: Alice Van Vliet papersSub-series 5.1: Faculty administrative files0.75 Cubic Feetin nine boxes1883-2006
Scope and Contents
Sub-series includes the minutes of the Academic and Collegiate Teachers' Associations and other faculty organizations, dating from 1883 to the 1970s. The various faculty committee minutes provide insight into the inner-workings of Packer drawn from the perspectives of faculty members. The minutes include draft examination schedules and letters to the Teachers' Associations from students and staff. Additionally, the sub-series contains faculty manuals (1967-1982), directories (2002-2006), and assorted miscellaneous files.Teachers' Meetings Minutes1883-1884Academic Teachers' Association – Minutes1927-1951Academic Teachers' Association – Minutes1958-1961Academic Teachers' Association – Minutes1958-1971Collegiate Teachers' Meetings – Minutes; Volume I1921-1925Collegiate Teachers' Meetings – Minutes; Volume II1926-1936Collegiate Teachers' Meetings – Minutes; Volume III1936-1947Collegiate Teachers' Meetings – Minutes1948-1950Collegiate Teachers' Meetings – Miscellaneous Minutes; Removed from meeting notebooks between 1948 – 19501948-1950Collegiate Teachers' Meetings – Miscellaneous Minutes1951Joint Academic and Collegiate Teachers' Meetings – Minutes1944-1958Correspondence and handwritten records of Faculty Club (Shop Club) removed from a ledger of minutes1949-1970Shop Club VIT.I1913-1918Shop Club VIT.I (papers removed from Shop Club ledger)1913-1918Shop Club receipts (removed from Shop Club Book VIT.I)1913-1918Faculty Shop Club Minutes1949-1970Miscellaneous faculty meeting minutes: Faculty Meeting minutes, 1941 – 1949; Presidents Council Meeting minutes, 1944; Faculty Advisory Board minutes, 1938 – 1949; Presidents Council Meeting minutes, 1951 – 19551938-1955Miscellaneous Faculty Meeting ReportUndatedFaculty and Staff Manuals1964-1973Faculty Manual1967-1969Faculty Manual1967-1979Faculty and Staff Manual1982Faculty and Staff Directory1980-1981Faculty/Staff Directory2002-2006Faculty questionnairescirca 1940sFaculty/Staff Get-togethers and Alum Cocktail Party2004-2006To Review (Faculty Miscellaney)1945-1999Clara Crampton Memorial Fund1943Faculty Publication Clippings1935-1983Sub-series 5.2: Development Office Faculty files4.25 Cubic Feetin eleven boxescirca 1840s-2007
Arrangement note
Arranged alphabetically by surname.
Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains files on individual faculty members, as well as faculty events and clubs, which were collected by Packer's Development Office. The dates of the material range from circa 1840s to 2007. An incomplete finding aid that includes dates through 2006 for faculty members containing name, subject taught, and date of death can be found at the beginning of the sub-series.
Included in this series are correspondences between faculty members; the writings of faculty members; newspaper clippings; personal letters and obituaries. The majority of faculty files are composed of information questionnaires and/or the initial employment applications. Individual faculty files of particular interest are Caroline Chesebrough, a 19th century writer; Bruce Tulloch, former Director of the Upper school; Eleanor Bannister, class of 1875 and distinguished artist who painted many portraits of Packer notables; Alex Bernstein, son of Leonard Bernstein; and Stephen Koplowitz, professional dancer/choreographer and director of Packer's dance program from 1984 onward.Finding Aid for Faculty Files A-Z 1870 – 20062006Abel, Raymond1870-2007Abdale, Darlene1870-2007Acerboni, Alexandrine1870-2007Acker, Sarah I.1870-2007Adams, Vera M.1870-2007Addams, Jessie1870-2007Ake, Nancy1870-2007Albaugh, Carolyn1870-2007Albino, Allison1870-2007Alden, Edmund K.1870-2007Alden, Edmund K.1896Alden, Mary1870-2007Allen, Alice1870-2007Allen, Margaret1870-2007Allen, Rhoda1870-2007Alt-Müller, Helen1870-2007Amighi, Jamshid1870-2007Anderson, Hazel V1870-2007Anderson, Lois1870-2007Angas, Frances Louise1870-2007Angas- Moore, Jean1870-2007Anthony, Julia1870-2007Appleton, Janet1870-2007Armington, Sarah R.1870-2007Armstrong-Acres, Irene1870-2007Arnaud, Octavie1870-2007Atkind, Russell S.1870-2007Atkinson, Ruth1870-2007André, Ninon Toumanoff,1870-2007Augustine, Lucy1870-2007Austegard, Audrey1870-2007Avery-Meding, Anne1870-2007Babbidge, Doris1870-2007Babbott, Frank l.1870-2007Badgeley, Elizabeth W.1870-2007Badué, Jose1870-2007Badwick, Edward1870-2007Bahner, Mary Bourquin1870-2007Bain, Therese1870-2007Bartinger, Shirley Armitage1870-2007Baldwin, Marjorie1870-2007Ballow, Margaret1870-2007Balsam, Geraldine1870-2007Bannister, Eleanor1870-2007Bannister, Lois1870-2007Barkalow, Winifred Bergen McAuliff1870-2007Barker, Henrietta F1870-2007Barrett, Judi1974

Scope and Contents
The sub-series consists mainly of handwritten drafts and typescripts of correspondence and manuscripts, along with a smaller quantity of poems and plays by Alice Van Vliet, who was a Latin teacher at Packer Collegiate Institute from 1901 to 1905. The bulk of material in this collection dates from 1924 to 1927, when Alice Van Vliet studied and received honors in Classical Moderations at Oxford University in England and toured around post-WWI Europe. Van Vliet documented her experiences in a travel journal and letters that she composed to a large group of friends back in America.
Biographical note
Alice Van Vliet was an American, born on January 11, 1874, and died at age 61 on September 6, 1935. The first available reference to Alice Van Vliet is from the Brooklyn Daily Eagle newspaper, which reported that in 1898 Van Vliet was a teacher at the Berkeley Institute (now the Berkeley Carroll School), an all-girls school started in 1886 in Brooklyn, New York. Following this, she was a Latin teacher at Packer Collegiate Institute from 1901 to 1905. Van Vliet is listed as a reader for the College Entrance Examination in 1906, where her title is given as "Director of Latin and Greek" at Packer, and she is credited with holding an A.B. from the University of Chicago, granted 1896. The last known teaching position that Van Vliet occupied was in 1926 and 1927 at the Katherine Branson School in Ross, California.
A book of Van Vliet's poetry entitled Poems was published in 1937, two years after her death. The dedication reads, "in memory of Alice Van Vliet, January 11, 1874 - September 6, 1935, from her friends, to her friends".
Arrangement note
The series is organized into two sub-groups:
Sub-group 5.3.1: Manuscripts
Sub-group 5.3.2: Travel Log/Diary Entries, Correspondence and DraftsSub-sub-series 5.3.1: Manuscripts1905-circa 1910
Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains four poems, two plays, miscellaneous manuscripts, and a collection of handwritten copies of Ovid poems. They are all in good condition, though the handwritten material from the early part of the 20th century shows signs of brittleness and age, and can be difficult to read.Poetry1905-1910

Scope and Contents
The sub-series consists mainly of handwritten drafts and typescripts of correspondence. This includes drafts of letters written by Alice Van Vliet and letters she received while she studied Classical Moderations at Oxford University, England, and traveled throughout Europe during the post-WWI period, 1924-1927. They conclude with correspondence from her time as a teacher at the Katherine Branson School in Ross, California. The tone of these letters is chatty and conversational, revealing personal experiences and the thrill of traveling and studying Classical Moderations at Oxford —referred to as "Mods" in many of her letters and diaries. The material in this Series is in good condition; most are not brittle, though some are difficult to read. Several of the letters were composed while on trains or boats and later typed. Because many of these letters are drafts, the paper is sometimes thin, the handwriting informal, and Van Vliet would often write on both sides of the paper in ink, which would seep through to the other side, thus making the letters almost entirely illegible.Travel Log/Diary Entries, Correspondence and Drafts1924

Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains meeting minutes and reports of the Committee on Instruction, Philanthropic Committee, House Committee reports, the report of the Committee for the Study of Co-education, the report of the Visiting Committee of Packer Collegiate Institute, and other committees, dating from 1885 to 1974. The Committee on Instruction meeting minutes document school related issues concerning faculty salaries, tuition rates, and graduation requirements. Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains Packer Collegiate Institute annual reports, dating from 1938 to 2014.
The reports include a variety of information in addition to financial matters, such as additions to the pre-existing curriculum and field trips intended to prepare students for the SAT exam (1950-1951), which was introduced in 1949 by the College Exam Board. A report from 1938-1968 includes information regarding male admissions, added courses, extracurricular activities, and the damages from the 1964 fire.

Arrangement
Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains assorted financial records, dating from 1845 to 1994. It contains fundraising and administrative budget materials, including ledgers for the Mrs. Packer Memorial Window Fund, 1906-1909; Treasurer's Reports, 1912-22; and the Administrative Budget, 1922-1934. It includes typewritten and bound minutes of Packer's Committee on Finance, 1951-1968; and an itemized valuation of the Institute's stock holdings as of February 2, 1955, which summarizes the division of the school's $938,761.00 market investment, the bulk of which was committed to government bonds, public utilities, and chemical stocks. Other materials include a cash ledger, 1892-1904; the ledger for the Memorial Window fund, 1905-1906; the Backus Memorial Fund account book, 1908-1909; a plea for funds letter signed collectively by the board of trustees, 1917; Packer alumni pledge cards, 1917; an Endowment fund ledger, 1917-1921; check stubs, 1926-1932; and Centennial Fund documents, 1945-1961. The series also contains student tuition bills, 1866-1916.
Related records can be found in Series 12: Development Office, Fund Raising, and Alumni records.Stock payment receipts1845

Scope and Contents
This sub-series is composed of material regarding the Emery Pension Fund, created by Mary M. Emery in memory of Adeline L. Jones in 1945 with a $50,000 gift in bonds to be used for the payment of pensions to retired teachers of Packer. Packer Current Items was first published in 1909 – a copy of vol. 1, issue 1 is included in this series. The publication continued into the twenty-first century, marking it as the longest-running student publication at Packer. Date, volume and issue numbers are sometimes inconsistent. A few issues are missing (see container list for details). Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains an assortment of material relating to Packer students, including school work, scrapbooks, autograph books, correspondence, class and club meeting minutes, artwork, and ephemera, dating from 1837 to 2009.
Some highlights include:
The scrapbook of Mrs. Paul D. Shafer (1940s-1950s), which primarily contains information and clippings about her husband (Packer president); Mrs. Harriet Pecket Cabbage's scrapbook, which contains updates on members of her class (1901), including correspondences and family information, including birth and death dates; the 1893 scrapbook of Louise Van Arden, which contains a letter from Florence Nightingale congratulating Van Arden on her graduation; Bernice Dhuy's chemistry, physics, and psychology compostions books (1903-1905); and student accounts of September 11, 2001.Letters from Cordelia Hale to Pamela Hale1837-1862

Arrangement note

Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains material pertaining to Packer's theater productions, dating from 1859 to the 2000s. Student productions were split into senior and junior performances during the theater's later years. Most of the images, press coverage, and papers in the series collection address senior productions. The students staged a Christmas Pageant every year that included a theatrical reenactment of the Nativity. In addition, repertory and modern productions were performed in the early spring of each year. The stage sets were built and the performances directed by students with adult guidance. In 1979, Packer Theater celebrated its 125th Anniversary by hosting "Today & Yesterday." For publicity purposes, retrospective material was collected about past theater productions for the Packer "Pelican" yearbook. Contents relating to individual plays vary, ranging from photographs and news clippings to promotional material, playbills, scripts, personal notes, and stage budgets.
The sub-series also includes some items relating to the Alumnae Dramatic Association.
Additional programs can be found in Sub-series 12.4: Curriculum files. Additional photographs of theatrical productions are found in Sub-series 17.1: Packer Collegiate Institute photographs. Audiovisual recordings of theatrical performances can be found in Sub-series 18.5: Theatrical recordings.125th Anniversary Performance - Today & Yesterday – Cast, Script, Playbill1979125th Anniversary Performance - Information pertaining to past performances1903-1949125th Anniversary Performance - Information pertaining to past performances1950-1972Alice in Wonderland1960Alice in Waterland1941Alma Mater Pageant, Founder's Day1949Antigone1944Anything Goes1989

Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains the collected papers of two individual students, Susan Losee and Elizabeth Post Morrow.
Arrangement
The sub-series is organized into two sub-sub-series:
Sub-sub-series 8.5.1: Susan Losee
Sub-sub-series 8.5.2: Elizabeth Post MorrowSub-sub-series 8.5.1: Susan Losee0.7 Cubic Feetin six folders1865-1869
Scope and Contents
This sub-sub-series contains the student papers of Susan E. Losee (Nichols), dating from 1865 to 1869. Papers include written exams, essays, lecture notes and exercise books, including a handwriting practice book, and cover a wide range of subjects, including French history, mythology, Latin, astronomy, geography, physiology, grammar/spelling, etc. Also included is a personal scrapbook of classmates' written entries. Eight illustrated "Reward of Merit" cards, awarding student achievement, are included, along with a Certificate of Academic Scholarship issued by Packer for admission to the University of the State of New York, dated 1869.Recognition and Certification of Scholarship1869Exams and exercises (two folders)1865-1868Notebooks, lecture notes, essays, scrapbooks1866-1868Composition book1866-1868Student poetry, "Home Again" Packer poem1868Exam questions1868Sub-sub-series 8.5.2: Elizabeth Post Morrow2 Cubic Feetin four boxes1880-1978
Biographical note
Elizabeth Post Morrow (1896-1992), the daughter of James Howell Post (President of the National Sugar Refinery) and Louisa Henderson Wells, was a student at the Packer Collegiate Institute, graduating in 1916. Her mother was also a Packer Institute Alumna (class of 1880), as was her daughter Betsey (class of 1943). As a student, Elizabeth Post was active in Glee Club, school plays and debates. She also was active in the Student Settlement Association. She lived in Brooklyn Heights after graduation (Remsen Street), and from the evidence of programs in her papers; she continued to attend Packer functions in the decades following her graduation. She married Thomas Morrow in 1920 and was identified as a philanthropist in a newspaper clipping found in one of her hymnals. She was Vice President of the Associate Alumnae of the Packer Collegiate Institute (years unknown). In 1937 she was appointed to the Packer Collegiate Institute Board of Trustees as the representative of the Association of Alumni. In the same clipping mentioned above, it was noted that she was the 6th woman appointed to the board, and her role was to help bring Packer policies in line with other similar educational institutions. Some time in the 1920s Elizabeth and Thomas Morrow established a homestead in Brookhaven, Long Island, where the Morrow family had formerly lived. The Post-Morrow Homestead in Brookhaven has become the headquarters of the Post Morrow Foundation, which was established by Elizabeth and Thomas to help preserve the rural character of Brookhaven and its surrounding areas in Suffolk County. Well into the 1970s Mrs. Morrow continued to give regularly, and often generously, to Packer funds.
Arrangement note
The sub-sub-series is organized into four sub-sub-sub-series:
Sub-sub-sub-series 8.5.2.1: School Memorabilia
Sub-sub-sub-series 8.5.2.2: Hymnals
Sub-sub-sub-series 8.5.2.3: Packer Events
Sub-sub-sub-series 8.5.2.4: Alumni ActivitiesSub-sub-sub-series 8.5.2.1: School Memorabilia0.4 Cubic Feet1880-1918in eight folders
Scope and Contents
The sub-sub-sub-series contains Packer memorabilia, dating from 1880 to 1818. It includes some material (commencement program and issues of The Packer Alumna), which predate Post's school career. These items possibly belonged to her mother, who also attended Packer. Alternatively, Post may have acquired these items during her tenure as an officer of the Associate Alumnae or on the Packer Board of Trustees.
The bulk of the files date from Elizabeth Post's school career and the years immediately following. These include school publications; a collection of programs of student plays, Glee Club performances, debates and school wide events (1909-1918); a 1913 exam; the script of "A Rose of Plymouth Town" with acting notes throughout for the role of Resolute Story, played by Elizabeth Post; programs of plays performed by the School Settlement Association; a handmade 1914 Packer calendar; and a Packer Anthem Book.Commencement Programs 1880 – 1887, and pre-1909 school items1880-1908The Packer Alumna1902, 1917Current Items and Clippings1911-1917School Activities1909-1918Rose O' Plymouth Town1915School Settlement Association programs1910-1918Packer Calendar1914Packer Anthem Book1890sSub-sub-sub-series 8.5.2.2: Hymnals0.7 Cubic Feet1895-1925, 1951in one box and four folders
Scope and Contents
Several hymnals seem to be Post Morrow's personal copies, with editions from various years. The hymnals list Charles Taylor Ives and Raymond Huntington Woodman as editors. Most are in fragile condition. Several contained printed or mimeographed lyric sheets. The hymnals sometimes contain ephemera, including painted place cards (including ones for "Mrs. Pratt," "Mrs. Morrow" and "Dr. Brockway"), a clipping announcing the appointment of Morrow to the Packer Board of Trustees, and the Annual Sermon to the graduating class of 1925.Hymnal1913Hymnals (includes lyric sheets and sermon) (6 folders)1895-1925Hymnals (3 folders)1901, 1951Sub-sub-sub-series 8.5.2.3: Packer Events0.2 Cubic Feet1916-1951in five folders
Scope and Contents
This sub-sub-sub-series include files of major events at Packer, or materials around a specific topic that were kept separate by Elizabeth Post Morrow in her original files. File 1 contains 75th anniversary materials (1928) including invitations, programs around various celebratory events, as well as a pamphlet history of Packer 1853-1928. File 2 has a few items related to a dinner in honor Dr. John H. Denbigh (1937). Dr. Denbigh retired that year as president of the Packer Collegiate Institute. File 3 contains clippings, invitation, and programs for the Edwin Jasper Memorial Lectures (1938-1937). Robert Moses was the speaker in 1939. These are fragile and need encapsulation. File 4 contains Centenary Celebration programs, invitations, lyric sheets and other related from 1945. File 5, Class of 1916 Material, contains items found in an envelope related to the class of 1916, including invitations to special graduation events in 1916, dance cards, and programs. This file also has notes and clippings related to reunions in 1937 and 1966.75th Anniversary Celebration1928Dinner to Honor Dr. John H. Denbigh1937Edwin Jasper Goodwin Memorial Lectures1938-1939Centenary Celebration1945Class of 1916 Materials1916-1951Sub-sub-sub-series 8.5.2.4: Alumni Activities0.7 Cubic Feet1929-1978in one box and three folders
Scope and Contents
The bulk dates of the material are 1937–1972. The files contain a mixture of materials generated by the Associate Alumnae of the Packer Collegiate Institute, Packer itself, and personal notes from the school administration or other alumna to Elizabeth Post Morrow. The majority of the records are fund raising letters, reports, brochures and event ephemera. Some of these materials are informative, especially letters and reports to the Associate Alumni written by Packer president John F. Skillman. Topics cover the financial troubles or well being of the school, enrollment concerns (1952), closing of the junior college (1971) and the decision to become a co-educational school (1972). There are a few hand written memos relating to Associate Alumnae business, mostly dating from late 1930s to the early 1950s. Other materials include invitations and programs of school events, reprints of speeches by Packer presidents, promotional brochures (some of these have photographs), newspaper clippings covering Packer news, announcements of changes in administration, and expansion of the school facility. Materials of particular interest are: a report card from 1930s reflecting concerns with appearance and deportment, a 1972 Coeducation Study Preliminary Report, a study on the junior college, and a 1969 letter from President on changes being considered to the school. There are several issues of the Packer Times from 1972–1973.Alumni materials (3 folders)1929-1945Alumni materials (7 folders)1947-1978Sub-series 8.6: Student Directories2.5 Cubic Feetin five boxes1972-2012
Scope and Contents
The sub-series consists of student directories, dating from 1972 to 2012.
One item of note is a copy of the 1977-1978 directory that includes a tally of the students' ethnicities by grade level.

Scope and Contents
The series contains items related to school events (commencements, Class Days, anniversaries, etc.) and daily diaries which record events and other day-to-day matters at Packer, dating from 1846 to 2015.
Additional event programs can be found in Sub-series 11.1: Administrative files, Sub-series 12.4: Curriculum files, Sub-series 12.10: Alumni Questionnaires, and Sub-series 12.15: Alumni Association Geographic Chapters.
Programs for Packer theatrical performances are filed in Sub-series 8.3: Packer Theater.
Additional files relating to commencements are available in Sub-series 12.5: Graduation files.
Items relating to Alumni Events are filed in Sub-series 12.14: Alumni Events and Sub-series 12.15: Alumni Association Geographic Chapters.
Photographs of events can be found in Series 17: Photographs and audiovisual recording of events can be found in Series 18: Audio, film, and video recordings.

General note
Donated in memory of Martha Atwater, 2013Sketch of the Life, Character and Work of Alonzo Crittenden (two copies)1885Sub-series 10.2: Truman Jay Backus1.5 Cubic Feetin four boxes1880s-1928
Scope and Contents
This sub-series includes two significant sets of correspondence. The first is correspondence to/from Dr. Truman Jay Backus (1842-1908), President of the Faculty at Packer Collegiate Institute from September 1883 through March 1908. The range of topics covered in this correspondence to/from Dr. Truman Jay Backus (1842-1908) includes scholastic accommodations and referrals for students, scholarship recommendations, faculty accommodations, and recommendations for teacher applicants and administrative matters such as building maintenance and facilities.
The sub-series has been broken into four sub-sub-series that include: 1) Multiple Correspondences arranged alphabetically by name; 2) General Correspondence between teachers; 3) Chronological files; and 4) Biographical/Memorabilia of Truman J. Backus
Multiple Correspondences
Highlights from this sub-sub-series include correspondence with William C. Lawton which constitutes a full exchange between Lawton and Dr. Backus about a teaching position, including interesting professional negotiations. Mr. Lawton did not end up teaching at the school. Noteworthy are the teacher recommendations made to Backus by Miss Lucy M. Salmon, Associate Professor of History at Vassar.
Additional materials include a folder containing correspondence between Backus and members of the Board of Trustees including letters from Board member Seth Low (1850-1916), who was the Mayor of Brooklyn, the Mayor of New York City, and served as the President of Columbia University. It also includes a six-page letter from Mr. McKeen, board member, in opposition to recommendations to the board to increase tuition. Also of noted significance is the last folder in the sub-series: correspondences between parents and Dr. Backus (1882-1891). The topics covered in this set include parental concerns over scarlet fever, scholarships, and lunch dismissals.
General Correspondence
Contains letters between Truman J. Backus and members of the teaching faculty. There is a letter written by Backus to the teaching staff asking for their opinions on the usage of the phrases "awfully bad" and "awfully pretty" (1900) and several responses from the teaching staff.
In addition, an eight-page letter from the Committee on Instruction (1899) regarding the possible reduction in teaching staff; a twenty page Report from Dr. Backus to the Committee on Instruction (1886) regarding curriculum; reports from Miss Susan K. Cook, teacher of "Mental and Moral Philosophy"; a report on individual teacher performance and recommendations about changes in assignments for teachers. This final report provides instructions on teaching etiquette accompanied by a 3 page statistical report.
Chronological files
Includes folders that span the years 1883-1894 with the exception of 1893.
Biographical/Memorabilia of Truman J. Backus
Contained in this sub-sub-series are 1) Published items written by Dr. Backus and 2) Biographical material about Dr. Backus. There is a short pamphlet written by Dr. Backus entitled: "Various Phases of an Important Subject" pertaining to the education of Blacks in the South, published by American Missionary Association, 12 pages. This sub series also contains a memorial essay written about the school's founder, Harriet Packer by Dr. Backus, and describes the education of young women in Brooklyn, in addition to detailing the first meeting between Dr. Backus and Mrs. Packer.Allinson, Francis G. Sugimoto1921Articles written by or about Denbigh1930sSub-series 10.5: Paul D. Shafer2.8 Cubic Feetin seven boxes1938-1960s
Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains assorted materials from Packer Collegiate Institute's President Dr. Paul Shafer, 1938 – 1968.
The first group of materials consists of speeches delivered to students, faculty, parents and/or alumni by Dr. Shafer between 1930-1953. The speeches address WWII and its impact on education. Speeches following WWII are addressed to the PTA and focus on education within the home. Two examples of Shafer's writings appear in print outside of the Packer community: Forbes Magazine and Vital Speeches of the Day. A large formal document, with the signature and official seal of New York City's Mayor, Fiorello H. LaGuardia, and names Shafer a trustee of the Brooklyn Public Library. Shafer's 1967 announcement of his retirement is also included in the series by the Alumni Association. Materials are in good condition, although, Vital Speeches of the Day magazine's condition is deteriorating and should be handled with care.
The secound group of material consists of Dr. Shafer's office files. Arranged in rough chronological order for the academic years between 1960-1967. Folders include: Annual Report, Daily Program, Finances, School Organization and Administration and Teacher Reports. Items within this group detail Dr. Shafer's philosophy of education, his leadership style and his thoughts regarding topical issues pertaining to the school as a whole. The format of materials ranges from printed programs to handwritten notes on 4 x 7 colored note cards.
The Annual Report folders contain President Shafer's notes in preparation of his reports to the Board of Trustees. The Daily Program folders contain Dr. Shafer's notes for addresses to groups including the Board of Trustees, faculty, and students at the beginning of the each school year. Many notes are typed with handwritten edits while others are handwritten. There are printed programs for school events such as theater performances or the Christmas Carol Sing. There are minutes from meetings of the Board, and there are lists such as, "Colleges entered by graduates of the Academic School."
The Finance Reports are inconsistent between 1960 and 1968. The Treasurer of the Board of Trustees is responsible for delivering these reports detailing school expenses for events such as theater performances or the Spring Concert.
The School Administration and Organization folders contain items dealing with campus life and the President's responsibilities. Some items are related to the faculty such as a description of the school's Major Medical Insurance policy coverage and a list of new teachers, or instructions, such as "Procedures for Examinations." Some items detail student life, for example Permission Slip forms for a school dance or a directive regarding the lapsed enforcement of rules prohibiting girls from leaving school between the times of arrival and dismissal. Miscellaneous items include air raid drill instructions and a list of families with two or more children in the school.
The Teachers' Report folders are comprised of evaluations by faculty members, reports on the activities school clubs and reports from the dean and department heads. Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains materials generated by and produced for the Office of Public Relations, dating from 1937 to the 1990s (primarily dating from the 1970s to the early 1990s). The items include interoffice memos among staff; correspondence between staff and advertisers, newspapers, educational directories, as well as correspondences between the Public Relations office and faculty, parents, and students. It also contains minutes from weekly meetings and school related conventions. Other materials includes: programs and academic schedules, handouts, scratch paper, bills, school histories, newsletters, and memos concerning school lectures and events.American College Public Scope and Contents
The sub-series consists of scrapbooks maintained by Packer staff, with items dating from 1848 to 1993. They contain newspaper clippings, photographs, letters, and programs pertaining to the students, faculty, alumni, and school events. Most newspaper clippings are taken from publications such as the Brooklyn Eagle. Includes six issues / Snapshots ended in January 2005, when information was disseminated via Packer's new website.Sub-series 12.3: Scholarship Fund Donors1 Cubic Feetin three boxes1880s-1970s
Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains correspondence between scholarship fund donors, their agents and staff members of Packer Institute, as well as copies of donor wills, dating from the 1880s to the 1970s. The correspondence includes handwritten records of individual contributions to a variety of funds and scholarship programs, typed correspondence from donor attorneys, unofficial memos and cleared checks. In addition, overviews of various scholarships and miscellaneous financial records related to scholarships and funds are housed in the first file in the sub-series, "Packer Scholarship Fund, General".

Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains materials relaingd to extracurricular activities of both students and alumni, dating from 1955 to 2007. The original folders were labeled "Curriculum Articles" and arranged according to specific programs, but also contained some unrelated material. Each folder contains clippings from internal and external publications, programs, flyers and registration forms relating to community service, culture, and events at the school. Of interest are some of the photographs, negatives and programs from Packer productions such as the "Dance Concert Programs" and other student productions.Awards: Academic awards, Activity Awards, Art and Writing Awards, Announcements and Ceremony Programs2002-2006Curriculum Articles: Cover/lead articles of The PRISM2001-2007Curriculum Articles: Cover/lead articles of Packer Magazine1999-2007Curriculum Articles: Cover/lead articles of Packer Alumna1963-1984PISDM – cover lead articles2007Curriculum Articles: Dance Concert Programs 1977-2000

Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains all of the Development Office files that pertain to Packer graduation ceremonies: graduation programs, speeches (including drafts and biographies with photographs of the speakers) in addition to paper work dealing with the administrative and organizational details of planning graduation ceremonies, i.e., ceremony memos, notes, correspondence with vendors and speakers, graduation reception invitations and even a couple graduation tassels. Arrangement note
Arranged chronologically by class year and alphabetically by name, with miscellaneous files placed at the end of the sub-series.
Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains alumni questionnaires for the classes 1848 through 2002. Some files also contain alumni correspondence, news clippings, photographs, wills and testaments, and miscellaneous material (e.g. keepsakes albums, invitations, commencement programs, class materials, theater programs, and relating to alumni activities). Records regarding alumni funds, donations, bankbooks, correspondence relating to financial support of the institution are also included here. One unique item in this series is a birthday note written on birch bark by Mary Bond (class of 1886), dated 1901. Highlights include alumni information on notable students such as Mary White Ovington (1890), one of the early founders of what is now the NAACP; Elizabeth Woodbridge (1890), one of the first women to receive a PhD from Yale University; Ruth St. Denis (1898), pioneer modern dancer (nee Ruth Dennis); Lucy Burns (1899), suffragette; Janet Gale (1929), Pro-Choice Activist for Planned Parenthood; Nancy (Charlotte) Cushman (1933), Broadway actress; Sybil Hart Kooper (1945), Judge; Carin Vilonen, Miss Finlandia of 1966; Nancy Goliger (1968), Director of Adelphi University; and Maria Yatrakes (1999), Scope and Contents
The series documents various alterations, renovations, and new construction at Packer, dating from circa 1880s to 2006. It includes plans, specifications, blueprints, correspondence, and related files.
School floor plans dating from circa 1860 are located in a bound volume labeled "Compositions," which is included in Sub-series 8.1: Student publications (box 497).
Arrangement
The series is organized into two sub-series:
Sub-series 14.1: Architectural drawings, plans, and administrative records
Sub-series 14.2: Playground designSub-series 14.1: Architectural drawings, plans, and administrative records2.3 Cubic Feetin five boxes and three oversize folders1856-2006
Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains architectural drawings, blueprints, floor plans, and projected renderings, dating from circa 1880s-2006.
It includes materials prepared by the Chapman, Evans, and Delehanty firm that document the extensive alterations and additions made to the Packer Collegiate Institute in 1957 and 1958. The various renderings and blueprints provide detailed information on Chapman's alterations. Large-scale floor plans of the entire campus are filed, as well as specific treatments of such areas as the dining room, gymnasium, sundeck, library, and greenroom.
The sub-series also includes drawings and blueprints created by various firms as proposals for the installation of the institute's steam heating system circa 1882. It is unclear which, if any of the firms, actually won the contract. Dated the same year is a correspondence from Otis Brothers & Company regarding the installation of an electric elevator. The company provided Packer with a blueprint for this elevator on June 5, 1891. The series also contains architectural blueprints and watercolors from 1944.
The plan books and specifications document a variety of alterations, building additions, and demolitions undertaken at Packer from the 1880s to the 1950s. The materials in the series affords researchers a vantage from which to better understand the architectural evolution of the campus at 170 Joralemon Street. Of special interest are: Architect William Tubby's specifications and instructions for the major alterations performed before World War I; James Gamble Rogers' materials and plans for the building's subsequent overhaul in 1940; the promotional materials describing proposed additions to mark Packer's centennial celebration in 1945; and intensive specifications describing the large-scale alterations performed in 1957 by Champan, Evans, and Delehanty.

Austin Organ CompanyAustin Pipe Organ1911-2006Series 17: Photographs58 Cubic Feet1845-circa 2010
Arrangement note
The record group is organized into seven sub-series:
Sub-series 17.1: Packer Collegiate Institute photographs
Sub-series 17.2: Photographic albums
Sub-series 17.3: Individual and Group Student photographic portraits
Sub-series 17.4: Administrators and Staff
Sub-series 17.5: Glass Lantern Slides and Negatives
Sub-series 17.6: Color slides
Sub-series 17.7: Postcards
Scope and Contents
The series contains photographs in a wide variety of formats, including, but not limited to, black-and-white and color prints, negatives, glass lantern slides, carte-de-visites, 35 mm slides, digital images, and postcards. In addition to loose photographs, the series includes a number of photographic albums and scrapbooks, most of which were assembled by students. The images span the history of the school, from 1845 to circa 2010. Topically, the photographs document students (incuding individual portraits, class portraits, various school events, and activities), administrators and faculty, and Packer buildings.
Additional photographs can be found in Sub-series 8.3: Packer Theater, Sub-series 11.2: Press releases and photographs, Sub-series 12.4: Curriculum files, Sub-series 12.10: Alumni Questionnaires, and Sub-series 12.14: Alumni events.Sub-series 17.1: Packer Collegiate Institute photographs50 Cubic Feetin 107 boxescirca 1850-circa 2010
Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains a substantial amount of photographs documenting life at Packer, dating from circa 1850 to circa 2010. It is primarily composed of prints, but also includes negatives (especially for photographs dating from the 1980s to 2000s), contact sheets, digital images, and other photographic mediums.
Thematically, the photographs cover various aspects of student life, including class work, arts, sports, class trips, special events, and extracurricular activities. It also documents the interior and exterior of Packer's building through the years.
The photographs were used for a variety of purposes, including the school's yearbook and various school publications.
Please note: many file descriptions include a five-digit, hyphenated number as part of the file description. These numbers are formatted XX-YYY, in which XX is a year indicator and YYY a sequential indicator. Thus, 98-002 indicates that the envelope is labeled as being from 1998, and is the second sequentially in its order, after 98-001 and before 98-003. These numbers were found on the envelopes in which the photographs were stored, and have been preserved to aid in the location of materials. However, they should be relied upon only with the understanding that not all photograph envelopes came with such a number, and thus the sequential ordering should be considered in no way absolute. In the instance that two photograph envelopes were found to possess the same numerical code, the two envelopes were designated within the file descriptions as variants (A) and (B) of the same five-digit code (ex: 98-002A and 98-002B).

Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains photographic albums, dating from 1864 to 1995. The albums primarily contain portraits of students, although the sub-series also include a 50th anniversary album and two albums relating to alumni.Photographic album1864

Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains portraits of Packer students, dating from 1853 to 2000s. It includes both indvidual student portraits and class group photographs. The photographs come in a variety of formats, including cabinet cards, cartes-de-visite, prints, tintypes, and digital images. Of note is a daguerrotype of the first graduating class of Packer Collegiate Institute.
It includes the photographs donated by: Mrs. Clifford Keep from 1874, Mrs. Bertha Richardson from 1875, Mrs. Judith E Wallingford from 1876, Mrs. Lulu M. Snyder from 1889, and Irene M. Biertenshaw from 1912.
Additional student and class portraits are found in Sub-series 17.2: Photographic albums.

Scope and Contents
The series contains audiovisual recordings in a variety of formats, including VHS cassettes, Betamax cassettes, Hi-8 cassettes, 8 mm cassettes, 3/4 inch tapes, 16 mm film reels, Mini DVs, DVDs, and audio cassettes. Subjects vary, and include events (especially graduation ceremonies), student theatrical performances, interviews with students and alumni, educational films, teacher seminars, and promotional videos. The tapes and reels date from 1933 to 2010.
Arrangement note
The series is organized into five sub-series:
Sub-series 18.1: Packer Institute Day in the Life Production
Sub-series 18.2: Film reels
Sub-series 18.3: Audio recordings
Sub-series 18.4: Video recordings
Sub-series 18.5: Theatrical recordingsSub-series 18.1: Packer Institute Day in the Life Production7.5 Cubic Feetin sixteen boxes1995-1996
Scope and Contents
This sub-series consists of Packer Institute's Day in the Life school production materials. Arranged by material type, this sub-series covers a time span of 1995-1996, with a significant portion highlighting 1995. A Day in the Life series highlights interview questions and discussions asked to a select 17 students and staff at Packer Institute to show the impact of Packer on their lives as well as show how they impact life at Packer. Interviewees are asked about academics, extracurricular activities, the building and grounds, interactions with students and faculty, and every day occurrences at Packer.
The 17 students and faculty interviewed for this production were: Erin Burke, Simone Callendar, Garfield Davidson, Abigail Hooper, Peter Kelly, Vanessa Olivieri, Chartey Quanceo, Susan Roos, Alliyah Rosenthall, Cynthia Rothschild, Ken Rush, Barbara Seadon, Denise Schweid, Ben Shopsin, Sueta Srinivasen, Laura Zinck, and Erland Zygmuntowicz.
Materials and Condition: Media formats include beta video tapes, Sony digital audio tapes, Hi8 tapes, and 3/4 inch tapes. A majority of the media used for this production was recorded by Winton DuPont Films. There are also film scripts and interview questions which are both on camera and off, and production notes. Film scripts are in good condition and transcribed by Herman S. General note

General note
Film stock in a metal reel with original cardboard Kodak container. Written in blue ink on front of container. "DANCE \ PACKER. SPRING, 1958." Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains audio recordings on cassettes and magnetic tapes, dating from 1946 to 1999. They include recordings of Packer events, educational conferences, and interviews with Packer alumni.
Arrangement
The sub-series is organized into two sub-sub-series:
Sub-sub-series 18.3.1: Events and other recordings
Sub-sub-series 18.3.2: InterviewsSub-sub-series 18.3.1: Events and other recordings2.2 Cubic Feetin seven boxes1946-1999
Arrangement
Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
The sub-sub-series consists of audio recordings relating to Packer, primarily audio cassettes with a few magnetic tapes, dating from 1946 to 1999. Included in the collection are various graduations and ceremonies throughout the years at Packer. For example, the introduction ceremony for Geoffrey Pierson in 1990. In addition, there are tapes documenting important seminars: ATIS (Association of Teachers of Independent Schools), meetings as early as 1980, NAIS (National Association of Independent Schools), on the role of the arts in education, and yearly NAIS meetings. Copies of a 1977 performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's Ruddigore, and a teacher's clarinet concert are among the series performance section. Finally, the miscellaneous material includes one tape in which the connection to Packer is unclear – a radio show playing music from the 1950s.Associate Alumnae magnetic tape1946Class Reunion 1952 – Music and News1952

Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains video recordings on VHS cassettes, DVDs, one Hi-8 cassette, and one Mini DV, dating from 1980s-2012. They include recordings on Packer events (especially graduations), promotional videos, educational seminars, and local news stories relating to Packer.
It includes a copy of the 1952 May Day celebration and commencement that has been transferred from film to VHS."For Packer Collegiate Grad-May Day 1952."1980s-1990s

VHS tape. Japanese language expose on the state of public education following fiscal crisis in New York City. Quality of public education is contrasted with that of private schooling. Packer Institute is cited as an example – clips show classes in action. Good audio/video quality."Show Close Bill 9/24/85. WABC-TV News. Bill Butel Ch7."1985

1988 February 16. VHS tape. Produced by WPIX Inc (NY). Tape is accompanied by letter dated March 24, 1988 from Warren Dean of WPIX Inc., addressed to MR. Hal Wicke, Director of Public Affairs at Packer. "Best Talk in Town" segment on Schomburg Center (and its role in preserving African American culture) is followed by an expose on student life at Packer. Narrator Warren Dean asks Packer students and teachers to identify Packer's special characteristics (in terms of teaching styles and learning environment). Video/audio quality is moderate. This is a 5th generation copy."Best Talk in Town Ch. 11, aired 2/26/88."1988

Packer, along with the UN International School, is cited as an example of independent schools. Richard Eyster, Packer Admissions Director is interviewed. Arrangement note
The series is organized into four sub-series:
Sub-series 19.1: Glass Lantern Slides
Sub-series 19.2: Textbooks
Sub-series 19.3: Nature Cards
Sub-series 19.4: Photo Cards
Scope and Contents
The series contains instructional material used at Packer, dating from 1803 to 1964 (primarily 19th century). It includes glass lantern slides depicting assorted locations and attractions, textbooks, nature cards depicting various plants and animals, and photo cards which survey the history of western art.Sub-series 19.1: Glass Lantern Slides0.5 Cubic Feetin two boxes1880s–1900s
Scope and Contents
The sub-series consists of glass lantern slides, dating from circa 1880s to the early 1900s. The lantern slides depict assorted locations and attractions taken at various times of the year in and around the United States (Niagara Falls; Yosemite Park; Old Faithful; Bee Hive Geyser, WY; a glacial fjord in Maine; a grain elevator in Illinois; a United State Navy warship; Luray Caverns, Virginia; Continental Divide and Grand Canyon, Colorado), Africa (DeBeers mine in South Africa; a caravan in Biskra, Algeria), Ireland (a peat bog in Killarney), and Australia (Tasmanian Forest).

No apparent order was found when processing. Owned by Barbara WinthropGreat English and American Essays: Revised and Enlarged, Edited by Douglass S. Mead1964Sub-series 19.3: Nature Cards0.5 Cubic Feetin four folders1873in one box
Scope and Contents
Series contains instructional nature cards depicting plants and animals, including varieties of wild cats, birds, roses and others. The 104 cards are printed on approximately 3x4 inch cardstock in vibrant full watercolor, and are in near perfect condition. Images are clear, not damaged and are encapsulated in mylar in pairs. Each card is stamped with the date 1873. The cards are in order of their natural family and species. Those depicting animals give a perspective side view and include small diagrams of jaws and feet for identification. The plants are shown from a top/side view of the plant and shown in full bloom. All cards are mounted on black card stock with a descriptor on the back of the plant or animal pictured.Letter of Introduction. Quadrupeds-Wild Cats-Carnivores, 11 cards. Plants-Pink Family, 11 cards1873Birds-Swimmers, 9 cards. Birds-Scratchers, 8 cards. Hollow Horn-Chewers (Cattle), 10 cards1873Plants-Lily Family, 10 cards. Birds-Waders, 11 cards1873Birds of Prey, 10 cards. Squirrel Family- Gnawers, 12 cards. Rose Family, 12 cards1873Sub-series 19.4: Photo Cards0.5 Cubic Feetin two boxes1880s-1900sin one boxOriginal order has been maintained.
Scope and Contents
Series contains 143 photo cards, which are photographs or prints mounted on heavy mat board. Images are mounted in both landscape and portrait orientation and vary in size. Mat board dimensions are predominately between 9x12 - 11x14 inches. Several prints are without mounting, all have been encapsulated. These photo cards were likely employed as visual aids in the teaching of a survey of western art and were often sold as thematic albums. The dates of use were likely during the last quarter of the 19th century through the early 1900s. The subjects of most of the images are Renaissance and Baroque art, including architecture (cathedrals, sculpture, plans, and elements), sculpture, paintings, and sacred decorative objects (reliquaries). Photographs were taken at the sites where their subject was created or resided at the time, which was primarily throughout northern Italy (Florence, Siena, Lucca, Pisa, and Venice). Many of the photographs include a caption or have a label fixed to mat board. A number of photo cards include maker's mark, the most prevalent being Alinari, the first and largest provider of these materials specific to the subject.70 Photo cards depicting Western Art and Architecture1880s-1900s73 Photo cards depicting Western Art and Architecture1880s-1900sSeries 20: Junior College1932-1972
Scope and Contents
The series contains files relating to Packer's Junior College, which operated from 1919 to 1972. It includes evaluation reports and a set of subject files which address various aspects of the school, dating from 1932-1972.
Academic records of Packer College students are located in Sub-series 3.2: Secondary and Junior College Transcripts.
Arrangement note
The series is organized into two sub-series:
Sub-series 20.1: Evaluation reports
Sub-series 20.2: Subject filesSub-series 20.1: Evaluation reports0.7 Cubic Feetin eleven folders1932-1970
Arrangement note
Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
This series contains reports of the inspection of Packer's Junior College for the purpose of receiving accreditation by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools (MSACS), dating from 1932 to 1970. It includes reports by the MSACS Commission of Institutions of Higher Education, as well as self evaluations by Packer. The reports detail observations and recommendations by Packer regarding its plans for the future and the fulfillment of its academic responsibilities. Topics include: setting, size, tradition, esprit de corps, purposes and objectives, programs, faculty, student services, library, admissions, alumni activities, and organization and administration.Packer Collegiate Institute Principle's Reports of Regents Exams January 1932—June 1937, and July 19491932-1949Report of the Evaluating Committee1944Evaluation of the Junior College - final report and other files1949The Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools Accreditation Evaluation Reports of Packer Collegiate Institute Junior College1949Report of Inspection of the Junior College1949Junior College evaluation letter and report of initiation of the Bayonne Junior College1949Evaluation report correspondence and notes1949Packer Collegiate Institute Survey of the Problem of Enrollment in PCI1953Packer Collegiate Institute Self Evaluation Report for Accreditation of Packer Collegiate Institute Junior College1959-1960The Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools Accreditation Evaluation Reports of Packer Collegiate Institute Junior College, 1960, and Evaluation of Packer Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, February 19601960Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools progress report1970Sub-series 20.2: Subject files5 Cubic Feetin eleven boxes1936-1972
Scope and Contents
The series is composed of records relating to Packer's Junior College, dating from 1936 to 1972.
It contains a variety of material, including sample forms and letters used by the admissions department; President Skillman's letter announcing the closing of Packer College; and various studies and requests for information. Of particular note are files relating to the closing of the school.
Other items include: Guidelines for the acceptance and entrance of non-matriculated students, foreign student forms, foreign student files, including applications, forms and information. Disadvantaged student forms, American Council on Education Bill to Amend Higher Education Act of 1965, a College Work study Manual , the "Campus Disturbance Report" that includes a statement entitled "Violence and Disruption on the U.S. Campuses from 1968-1969" by Adam E. Bayer and Alexander W. Astin that was issued by the American Council on Education.
Other materials consist of a "Bill of Rights" for students by Patricia Curtis. The historical significance of these documents exists on both a personal and local level as visible signs of the disruption of campuses by students protesting the war in Vietnam and Civil Rights issues as well as the "tragic events at Kent State University which sharply intensified their feelings and sense of need." – taken from Rights of the Student, "Confidentiality of Student Records."

Arrangement note
The series is arranged into five sub-series:
Sub-series 21.1: Honors and plaques
Sub-series 21.2: Textiles, banners, and flags
Sub-series 21.3: Pins, rings, and other metal objects
Sub-series 21.4: Exhibition items

Scope and Contents
This sub-series contains a variety of artifacts and memorabilia relating to the Packer, dating from circa 1780 to 2004. It includes awards and commemorations presented to students, personal items belonging to former students, textiles, promotional items, and architectural memorabilia. Items of note include two wooden primers (presumably used in the 19th century), an assortment of historical flags and banners dating as far back as 1890, class pins and rings, school uniforms, plaques, and other honors. It also includes items which were used in exhibitions which were displayed at the school. Some materials were donated by Mrs. T. Stewart Harris in 2001 and Ms. Mary Jean Eckhardt Howard (class of 1946).Sub-series 21.1: Honors and plaques18 itemsin seven boxescirca 1923-1999

Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains items that were used in historical exhibitions at Packer, dating from 1839 to 1945. Materials include photographic prints, cabinet cards, drawings, newspaper clippings, manuscript letters, fliers, notices, official documents, invoices, receipts and stock certificates. They were used in as many as three exhibitions, one of which was almost certainly the centennial exhibit of 1945.
There are several items of note relating to the founding of the Brooklyn Female Academy (BFA) in this sub-series, including a notice of meeting in Brooklyn to plan establishment of BFA, the floor plans of the BFA building, and an invitation to the opening of the school.Documents pertaining to the Founding and Origins of the Brooklyn Female Academy1846-1891Items Relating to the Packer family and the founding of the Packer Institute.1853-1930sIncludes portraits of the Early Presidents of the Packer Institute.1854-1938Images of PackerUndatedImages of Brooklyn1855-1945Commencements1852-1871Stock Certificates of the Brooklyn Female Academy1845Subway Construction – Request for Consent from Board of Rapid Transit Railroad Commissioners, June 141901Unknown PhotographUndatedMatthew Brady Cabinet Card of Walt Whitman1860sLetter from W.S. "Celebration of the Opening of the Packer Collegiate Institute for the Education of Females in the City of Brooklyn, November 9, 1854."1854Sub-series 21.5: Miscellaneous items3.4 Cubic Feetin fourteen boxes and one flat file drawercirca 1780-1995
Scope and Contents
The sub-series contains assorted items relating to Packer, including promotional items, dating from circa 1780 century to 1995. Of note is a handcolored engraving entitled "The Inthronization of their Majesties also a View of the West End of the Choir of St. Peters in Westminster, and of the manner of Placing and Seating the Company in that Part of the Choir" (circa 1780), which was donated to the school by Sydney W. Davidson in 1957. Davidson was a Packer Trustee. It also includes two wooden primers that might have been used during the early years of the school."The Inthronization of their Majesties also a View of the West End of the Choir of St. Peters in Westminster, and of the manner of Placing and Seating the Company in that Part of the Choir" handcolored engravingcirca 1780

Used by the Office of Development. Includes stamps for various rooms (Centennial Period Room, Packer Between the Wars Period Room, Disco Room) and events (Before the Bridge and Victorian Packer (1996)).Series 22: Packer family0.6 Cubic Feetin six boxescirca 1850-1990s
Scope and Contents
The series contains materials related to the Packer family (primarily Mrs. W.S. (Harriet L.) Packer, Miss Harriet P. Packer, and Mrs. W.S. (Mary K.) Packer Jr.), dating from circa 1850 to the 1990s.
Items relating to Mrs. W.S. (Harriet L.) Packer include her correspondences and a journal. The correspondence to and from Mrs. Packer covers a wide variety of topics. Mrs. Packer's journal details a trip to Europe taken between May and August of 1854. Also included in this series is a speech about Mrs. Packer by Mrs. Truman Jay Backus. The speech provides a description of Mrs. Packer's character, her devotion to women's education, and her vision of the Packer School.
The series includes material relating to the daughter of Mrs. W.S. Packer, Miss Harriet P. Packer, including a speech delivered at Packer's jubilee celebration and numerous letters regarding Miss Packer's death in 1909.
The series also contains the memoirs of Mrs. W.S. (Mary K.) Packer, Jr. The memoirs describe the impacts of the Civil War on the school, and family events such as the meeting with Mr. W.S. Packer Jr., her subsequent engagement and marriage to him. Historical information dealing with the aftermath of the Civil War: John Brown's raid, the nomination of Abraham Lincoln, the first Battle of Bull Run, Gettysburg, are the main subjects of individual chapters.
It also includes correspondence between Mrs. Packer and Mary discussing her attempt at attending college after a long period of absence due to poor health. The correspondence depicts a college bound curriculum.
The series also contains photographs (mostly reproductions) and portraits of members of the Packer family, including a daguerreotype of William Packer and images of the Packer mansion on Grace Court.Packer Family photographscirca 19th centuryPacker Family photographs (oversize)circa 19th centuryWilliam Packer daguerreotype1840s-1850sBenjamin Putnam portraitcirca 1850Letters from Mrs. William S. Scope and Contents
The series contains a variety of miscellaneous files that do not relate to the other series in the collection. It includes information on the Bates Collection and auction, inventories of silver and furnishings for the alumni lounge, and photographs of Brooklyn (unrelated to Packer). General
In 1948 Packer Institute sued the University of the State of New York contesting the university's attempts to regulate the institute's activities. The judge ruled in favor of Packer, ruling that only the state legislature had the right of oversight of Packer Institute.
